description: Mtatsminda Park is a historic amusement park perched atop Tbilisi's 'Holy Mountain' at 770 meters elevation, offering breathtaking panoramic views and over 100 hectares of entertainment. Originally established in the 1930s during Soviet times, it was once the 3rd most visited public park in the entire USSR. After decades of decline post-Soviet collapse, the park was magnificently revitalized in the early 2000s by the wealthy Patarkatsishvili family, transforming it into a modern 21st-century theme park while preserving its historic charm and cultural significance.
highlights: Giant Ferris Wheel - Standing 65 meters high at the mountain's edge, offering spectacular 360-degree views of Tbilisi and the Caucasus Mountains from glass cabins
Historic Funicular Railway - A Belgian-engineered marvel from 1905, still running on its original tracks after a 2012 renovation, connecting the city to the mountaintop

Mtatsminda Pantheon - A sacred burial ground established in 1929, where Georgia's most celebrated writers, artists, and public figures rest, including Alexander Griboyedov, Akaki Tsereteli, and Nikoloz Baratashvili
Mamadaviti Church - A late 19th-century church dedicated to Saint David Gareja, the 6th-century holy father who first settled on this 'Holy Mountain' to preach Christianity
Over 60 rides and attractions - Including roller coasters, water slides, carousels, Ghost Castle dark ride, video games, and shooting galleries
Tbilisi TV Tower - The 275-meter-tall iconic structure built in 1972, dominating the city's skyline
Funicular Restaurant - A legendary dining establishment housed in a magnificent 1938 building, once frequented by luminaries like Fidel Castro, Margaret Thatcher, and Alain Delon
Lower Funicular Station - A heritage architecture masterpiece designed by Aleksander Szymkiewicz, featuring elegant brick construction with arched windows and art deco details
tips: Visit in the evening to experience the magical panoramic views of Tbilisi's dazzling city lights at sunset - it's truly enchanting

Purchase a rechargeable park card (2 GEL, non-refundable) at ticket offices or the funicular station - individual attractions cost 1-5 GEL each. Don't overcharge the card as unused funds cannot be refunded
Take the historic funicular railway (8 GEL, operates 9 AM to midnight) for the most scenic and authentic arrival experience
For budget-conscious visitors: park entrance is FREE - you only pay for the funicular and individual rides you choose
Alternative transport: Take bus N90 or N124 from Rustaveli metro station, or hike up from Chonkadze Street (about 1 hour) for stunning views along the way
Try the famous donuts and Adjara khachapuri at the Funicular Restaurant near the park
Stop at the Pantheon on your way up to pay respects to Georgia's cultural giants - it's a moving experience
Arrive before sunset and stay after dark to experience the park's transformation from daylight beauty to nighttime magic
The park has restaurants, cafes, shops, relaxation zones, a celebration center, and even a wedding hall - it's perfect for a full day visit
Best for: Families, couples seeking romantic atmosphere, photography enthusiasts, and anyone wanting to experience Tbilisi's highest vantage point
vibe: Mtatsminda Park embodies a unique blend of nostalgia, romance, and modern entertainment. For locals, it's more than just an attraction - it's woven into Tbilisi's cultural identity as a beloved pastime spanning generations. The park carries echoes of Soviet grandeur mixed with contemporary Georgian pride, where families create memories on the same rides their grandparents once enjoyed. The atmosphere shifts from thrilling amusement park energy during the day to intimate, romantic ambiance at night, when couples ride the illuminated Ferris wheel above a sea of twinkling city lights. The 'Holy Mountain' setting adds a spiritual dimension - you can feel the weight of history from the 6th-century saint's legacy to the pantheon of Georgian cultural heroes. It's simultaneously playful and profound, commercial yet culturally significant, offering both adrenaline-pumping rides and contemplative moments gazing over the ancient city below. The restored funicular journey itself feels like traveling through time, connecting modern Tbilisi to its storied past while ascending toward breathtaking views and family fun.
